webTitle: Tesco climbs on talk it could pay £8bn back to investors and exit US business

fields.standfirst: Analysts at UBS raise their rating on supermarket group on back of expected cash returns
fields.body:
Tesco has been under cosh for a while, on worries about its UK growth and the success - or otherwise - of its international strategy.

But now the supermarket's shares are being lifted by talk it could return £8bn to shareholders over the next six years or so, and suggestions it should abandon its Fresh and Easy stores in the US.

UBS analyst Mike Tattersall moved his recommendation from neutral to buy and said:

We believe Tesco is recalibrating the manner in which value is delivered to shareholders by lowering capital intensity and focusing on cash generation. This has the scope to drive significant cash returns – our analysis suggests the company could feasibly buy back almost £8bn of equity and return around 60% of market cap to investors in cash, including dividends, over the period to February 2018.

He also suggested Tesco's trading performance in the UK was better than commonly perceived:

Overall, we see a credible roadmap over the coming 6-12 months whereby concerns over Tesco's core business are alleviated, releasing pressure on the rating of the shares which is close to 15-year absolute and relative lows.

As for Fresh and Easy, he believed shareholders would be pleased to see the back of the business:

Although we understand management's desire to give the Fresh and Easy concept every opportunity to prove itself, ongoing disappointments and the apparently insurmountable economics of the model make meaningful value creation a more distant prospect than ever. We argue that Tesco would benefit from exiting the US and believe investors would warmly welcome such a move.

The news has helped Tesco climb 6.1p to 314p.

webTitle: Xstrata moves higher despite production drop as FTSE 100 welcomes Spanish rating news

fields.standfirst: Mining group upbeat about fourth quarter, while investors back in risk-on mode
fields.body:
Mining groups are leading the market higher once more after Spain's flirtation with a junk bond rating was avoided, at least for the moment.

Xstrata has added 10.6p to 974.6p despite reporting a 16% dip in third quarter copper production compared to the same period last year. But the miner, in the middle of a drawn out merger attempt with Glencore, said a turnaround in Chile would help the fourth quarter. It also confirmed it had cut 600 jobs in Australia. Bank of America/Merrill Lynch said:

Broadly, most divisions run-rating was a little light versus our expectations, for a variety of reasons. Expect the shares to still be very much driven rather by the deal than by today's results. Keep in mind this is just one quarter worth of production, so not to get too too excited about and many of issues are one-offs. Maintain buy, Xstrata is our preferred entry into the "Glenstrata" combo.

The rest of the sector was lifted by renewed optimism about the eurozone and the global economy, with Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation climbing 11.2p to 339.6p and Rio Tinto rising 60.5p to 3121.5p.

Banks had a more mixed performance, with Royal Bank of Scotland up 6p at 286p after it said it would exit the government's toxic asset scheme on Thursday. But Barclays has slipped 3.15p to 242.95p after two days of gains.

Overall the FTSE 100 is up 11.40 points at 5881.94 after Moody's decided on Tuesday night not to downgrade Spain's credit rating, given its potential access to the European Central Bank's bond buying scheme. All eyes willb e on the EU summit in the next couple of days, as Greece's talks with its international creditors continue. President Obama's better performance in the latest US presidential debate was also welcomed - on the whole markets prefer political stability.

BAE Systems led the fallers, for once nothing to do with its botched plans to link up with EADS. Its shares fell 8.3p to 320.8p as they went ex-dividend.

webTitle: Young black men hit by sharp rise in unemployment

fields.standfirst: TUC report ahead of official unemployment figures finds more than a quarter of black 16 to 24-year-olds are out of work
fields.body:
Young black men have experienced the sharpest rise in unemployment since the coalition came to power, a TUC report showed ahead of official unemployment figures.

The TUC said more than one in four of black 16 to 24-year-olds are currently out of work. Young black men are more likely to be unemployed than any other ethnic group, although young Asian women have been hit by the biggest rise in unemployment over the past decade, up from 6% to 13%.

The TUC's general secretary, Brendan Barber, said: "The UK is in the midst of a youth jobs crisis. Over a million youngsters are out of work and many more are struggling to find the finances needed to further their education. Last week the prime minister singled out employment as a great success of the government. That's cold comfort to the one in four young black men struggling for work, or the one in six jobless young black women."

Overall, unemployment is expected to have been little changed last month, while earnings growth is set to have declined further, dealing another blow to squeezed households. Figures from the Office for National Statistics are forecast to show no change in the number of people claiming jobless benefits in September. The unemployment rate is seen steady at 8.1% in the three months to August.

Wage growth is expected to have fallen to 1.2% in the three months to August, from 1.5%. Earnings have failed to keep up with inflation, which is running at 2.2%.

"The resilience of the labour market has been much in the spotlight recently," said Philip Shaw, chief economist at Investec. "While we cannot explain this completely, at least part of the reason rests with the restraint in pay. Moreover job patterns are much more flexible – note that despite the material rise in employment over the past year, the number of full-time employees has fallen by 65,000 with part-time working and self-employment both rising significantly."

Behind the headline figures, the picture is worsening for young people. A study by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation found that up to 66 unemployed people are chasing every retail job and two thirds of those applying for jobs did not get any response. Vacancies were filled within days and in some cases hours.
